climbs.name: The Ukrainian Challenge
climbs.fa: Kevin Capps 2017, with Kirk Miller & Jake Burgart

content.description:
This is the incredible splitter and stem corner on the north side of Chimney Rock. A mellow start leads to a ledge, where you can rest up before pulling on some of the best crack climbing in the park. Aside from a good rest about halfway, this route is mostly sustained and includes finger locks, ring locks, a couple of hand jams, and a punch-it-to-the-chains type of finish.

It is worthÂ the hike!
content.protection: A double rack of cams from tips to fists and a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the obvious splitter crack and corner on the north side of the formation, right off the main trail.

content.description:
The first 70 feet go on bolts, and the final 50 feet go on gear.

Clip the Lost Arrow, and ascend an assortment of dihedrals and slabs. At the intermediate anchor, clip the right bolt, and step right into the trad section.

The traditional section ascends a variable width crack that in accordance to park rules avoids local flora. Generously, nature allowed for an exciting pathway though the vegetated cliff. Clip a final bolt, and gain the anchors.
content.protection: 12 draws. The rack used on FA had: 0.3, 0.3, 0.4, 0.4, 1, 2, 5, and 5. An extra large piece (4, 5, or 6) might make things more comfortable.
content.location: On the north side of Chimney Rock, locate the comfortable belay area and start at the short dihedral that contains a fixed piton.

climbs.name: Mantelpiece
climbs.fa: Kirk Miller, Adam H. Levine, Sept. 2018

content.description:
Mantelpiece is a 2 pitch route that summits the northeast side of Chimney Rock.

P1. Climb two slab sections split by a low angle crack. At the top of the slab, trend right to a 2 bolt anchor (5.11-).

P2. The second pitch heads up steeper ground on a patchwork of truncated aretes, bulges, and dihedrals. This geometry results in a number of mantels and rests that lead to an increasingly technical headwall before the topout (5.12-).

Rappel twice with a 60 meter rope.

Alternatively, the route can be climbed as a long single pitch as it was on the FA.
content.protection: 14 bolts supplemented by trad gear. No gear is required over a 0.75. Extra smalls (0.2-0.5) make things comfortable. Alpine draws are helpful, especially on the 2nd to last bolt on P2.
content.location: Find the main slab on the Northeast side of Chimney Rock. At its nadir, 3 right-trending bolts indicate the start of the route.

content.description:
This is the sport start to

Right Ear Up

. Since there is a natural stance before the trad section, I figured the route would get more traffic if I added an intermediate anchor.

The route does feel anticlimactic when climbed this way but is still worthy.
content.location: On the north side of Chimney Rock, locate the comfortable belay area and start at the short dihedral that contains a fixed piton.

climbs.name: The Learning Curve
climbs.fa: FA: Jake Burgart, Tyson Ferryman, Kirk Miller FFA: Jake Burgart

content.description:
The pristine location, quality of rock, and variance of movement and handholds on vertical granite rock will ensure that The Learning Curve leaves both a historic mark in Staunton State Park and a lasting impression on the climbing community.

The Learning Curve will test your strength, stamina, and route-reading ability over lengthy 5.11 climbing and multiple 5.12 cruxes. Rampy granite blocks and a thin face, which culminates in a technical, reachy crux comprise the first 60% of this route.

After a welcome rest, the eye-catching green lichen streak contains unrelenting thin, vertical crimping on wandering holds. The start of the green streak contains the main crux, which revolves around a large sloper. A redpoint crux defends the last bolt and anchors.

This is truly a masterpiece!

The largest thank you goes out to both Kirk Miller and Tyson Ferryman. The establishment of this climb never would have occurred without years of foresight and hard, dedicated work.
content.protection: 2 bolt anchor, 2 bolt belay, 2 alpine quickdraws, 19 quickdraws, and a 70m rope are required.
content.location: Look for the green lichen streak. Start directly below it, at the 2-bolt belay anchor, which is on the left hand side of the slab base.

climbs.name: Frances' Secret Handshake
climbs.fa: Kirk Miller, Tyson Ferryman, Jake Burgart

content.description:
This route is dedicated to Frances Hornbrook Staunton, whose generous contribution led to the creation of Staunton State Park.

The climb gets morning sun and afternoon shade.

Onsighting this route will test your 5.11 skill set for sure. Climbing the first pitch, you encounter very steep rock with tricky roof, thin face, and delicate slab cruxes. This can be a very demanding climb. With a little luck, you might even discover the secret handshake.

If you're gunning for the summit you'll have to complete the second pitch, move the belay right to set up. The second pitch pulls a bouldery move right off a ledge with a huge perched block at your back. To prevent both ledge fall injury and the distinct possibility of falling onto the block, this pitch was closely bolted.

The rap anchors are right of the finish and conveniently accessed from the last protection bolt.

Huge props to Tyson for re-discovering Chimney Rock. Thanks for bringing me to this amazing spire! Thanks also to Troy Tadlock for help with summit bolts and rap anchors. Bolting these routes is a ton of work, and it's great to have help!
content.protection:
First pitch: 19 bolts, 35 meters.

Second pitch: 7 bolts, 15 meters.

Strategic use of a few alpine draws on the first pitch helps reduce rope drag.

A 70 meter rope allows for lowering from the first pitch or rapping from the top with two raps (it's probably a good idea to knot the ends...).
content.location: It is located roughly in the center of the steep, Northeast face, right of The Learning Curve. A control bolt on the slab at the base marks the start.

content.description:
This route can be divided into 3 sections. In all 3, a brief 5.11-/5.10+ move yields fun practicable 5.10 climbing.

Use a long draw on the roof clip, and keep an attentive belay during the mantel off the large ledge.

-

A problematic high block temporarily shut down the development of this section of rock. Failure in extracting the block eventually led to a fresh look at the wall, and an unforeseen pure sport route emerged. The afternoon knows what the morning never expected.
content.protection: 14 bolts to Climbtech hooks. Use a 70m rope.
content.location: In the comfortable belay zone on the North side of the spire, locate a left-facing dihedral protected by 3 bolts.

content.description: For an ascent of this route, bring the big gear and be ready to use your route finding and offwidth skills.
content.protection:
A standard rack, singles to #6 Camalot, a #3 and a #4 Big Bro. There are a few old fixed pins high on the route.

The old summit anchors were kinda sketchy....

Three pins were pulled (too easily!) and were replaced with a new anchor in 2015. The summit now sports a stainless anchor with chain and rings (courtesy of ASCA) strategically placed where the Chimney Route tops out. Â From the chains, a 40 meter rap gets you down.
content.location: Once you've made the hike in, locate the obvious namesake chimney on the North face, wander up, and engage the wideness.
